author: yoouie
body: You can invest in companies that hardware vendor computer hardware(not the chip manufacturers like amd,Intel,Nvda) look into companies like msi edit(ticker name is micro star)

author: Lucrumb
body:
What makes Apple more unique I think is how immaterial their value is. They don't manufacture their own phones, Foxconn does iirc. Many of the parts for the iPhone come from Samsung etc. 

I think part of the popularity of Apple is due to how invested some people are in their "ecosystem". If you've spent £100s on iTunes music/apps, a docking station and iCloud storage, you might not buy an android even if they are better. Many don't like change, I'm guilty of this. I've owned mostly Samsung phones (tried Sony and Motorola, didn't like them as much) and I just can't be bothered to change to a device that has a different user interface etc. 

This complacency, combined with their "coolness" makes Apple valuable. And their devices aren't even bad, just slightly more expensive than the competition. I think the introduction of Apple + or whatever their streaming service is and their games subscription thing was a good move.

author: halhazard
body: AMD has some chip integration in China (where they put the actual silicon chip onto an integrated circuit with the pin outs.) All the GPU AIB partners for Nvidia and AMD (Asus, MSI, Gigabyte, etc) have manufacturing in China.

author: LoveItLateInSummer
body:
or not. issued forward guidance should already be priced in, and I don't mean that in the usual WSB way, it really should.  trick is to find company with same external dependencies causing AAPL to lower guidance but that hasn't issued statement yet, maybe samsung or motorola

But it's all gambling at this point - which is the way

author: PhilWham
body:
Good example on the potential time value of money but idk about the investing in Apple  stock analogy. 

Easy to say I should have invested in Apple in hindsight, but in reality some people did take similarly viable risks into Blackberry, Motorola, Blockbuster, Compaq during their rises/haydays and have been burned. 

Imo op your money would be better spent at this age investing in yourself (skillset, education etc) rather than stumbling upon/investing in the next big thing. The rule of 72 is a good indicator of what investing can more applicably do for op.

author: fugyu247
body:
They’ve all released their Tesla competitor and Tesla hasn’t lost market share though. As I said in my previous comment, they are still expanding their lead in innovative technology (batteries and AI) despite large investments from other legacy automakers Over the last 5 years+. 


There are a lot of comparisons to make to Apple here. An electric vehicle is fundamentally different than an ICE vehicle. A smart phone is fundamentally different than just a cell phone. Motorola and Nokia making good cell phones but never had a chance in the smartphone market because its not just adjusting your assembly line. It’s a completely different product. 


Institutional investors aren’t stupid. There’s a reason hedge funds hold Tesla stock and not Ford.

author: ConfidenceFairy
body:
NOK is currently priced very low. I think it would be a good acquisition target for some American company backed with private equity. Inside Nokia exist what was once Lucent Technologies, Bell Labs, Motorola wireless network infrastructure. 

The main reason for low price  is Nokia's [ReefShark](https://www.nokia.com/about-us/news/releases/2018/01/29/nokia-launches-reefshark-chipsets-that-deliver-massive-performance-gain-in-5g-networks/) chipset supplier (Intel) who could not deliver.  Nokia had to cancel dividends because  they need to spend more into R&D and redesign stuff.  Profit margins suffer because the FPGA based chipset is more expensive than anticipated.   This is probably just temporary setback but  very  bad one. There were even some rollout delays.  [
Nokia's 5G Chip Choice Leaves It Exposed
](https://www.lightreading.com/mobile/5g/nokias-5g-chip-choice-leaves-it-exposed/d/d-id/755184).

Digesting Alactel-Lucent acquisition resulted other problems but  those sould be over soon.

author: faithnoless
body:
I hope your teacher gives you the option of investing in more than one stock!  If I had that sort of cash for real, I'd put $5 into each of 20 different stocks.  If this started a week ago and you chose Tesla, then you'd be a happy camper right now!  But I think it'll pull back quite a bit after some hype wears off.  Stocks that shoot up very high and very quick like that always pull back, sometimes a lot.

The only thing I don't like about this project is how investing shouldn't be boiled down to weeks, but I guess that's all the time you have to work with in a school.  So my advice:  if you do this for real when you're older, think about 8 YEARS instead of just weeks or months!

Still reading, or getting bored yet?  Here are some picks:  Amazon, Mastercard or Visa, Shopify, The Trade Desk, Adobe, Cognex, MongoDB, Match Group, Okta, Stitch Fix, Square, Twilio, Zscaler, Zoom Video Communications, MercadoLibre, Wix, Roku, Nvidia, Netflix, Micron Technology.  Given your short time frame, some of these should give you a good boost during that time - unless the market has a bit of a correction, which it might because it's been "hot" lately.  Pick some, pick all, whatever your teacher lets you do.  Hope this helps!

author: ChompySnack
body: Small price stocks are hard to wheel. You need a very liquid options market or the spread will make it much less profitable. Also $2k is not nearly enough unless you want to hold a single risky and downtrodden stock that don’t generate much premium. With that little an amount you also won’t be able to diversify. It’s best not to hold more than 5-10% of your account in any one stock. If you can get margin on your account, skip the put phase and buy the stock and sell an ITM (I like around 70 delta) call. That’s the same trade as a short put but you can leverage 4x usually. You can find stocks that can average between 0.5-1.0% a week. Going out farther than one week reduces risk and return. Some of my go-to lower price stocks are SFIX, MU, SNAP, TWTR, BAC, CIEN, CSCO, LK, MU, T, WDC, and XLNX. Beware of earnings!

author: FreakingOutTheNGHBRD
body:
Anytime is good. MU is a cyclical stock (look up micron cyclical to see why) so just buy 100 shares and sell a covered call every month with a strike at least 50 cents above your average cost. If the stock slips too much and you can't get a decent premium selling a strike above your average cost, weigh your previous premium gains against that and lower your strike so that if the shares were called away, you wouldnt have lost money all things considered.

my average cost was like 49 for a while (its lower now) and the stock went down to the low 40's. I couldn't sell a $50 strike for more than like 60 bucks. But I had already made 6k selling calls on MU. So I said, let me sell a 45 call then for three months out and get a 900 premium. If it does hit 45, ill lose money, but not more than I've made in total selling calls against my shit.

that's just the way i think of it. but yeah i would just buy now while its below 60

author: freehouse_throwaway
body:
Ok day from my [dip-buying](https://www.reddit.com/r/wallstreetbets/comments/ewuvf8/weekend_discussion_thread_january_31_february_2/fg4jqk8/) on Fri:

* Dump V $202.5c for good gains. 30% on them (avg $1.4, out at $2)
* NVDA basically got out early before theta crushed it. avg 1.5, out at 1.65
* AIMT was only able to offload one fucking contract at open. RIP rest.
* ATVI continues to fuck me. Bought more.
* PTON looking good so far. Diamond hands.
* Closed out all my SPCE 2/21 $20c on this crazy ass close. Avg of .7 out at ~$1.20

honestly should have just sold puts with AIMT but didnt want to tie up capital.

MU is green today but got theta fucked. sigh. need this back to $55c fast or I'm fucked on these.
